data.sampled: No, this is not morally acceptable. Hank's decision to break all the windows in his neighbor's house goes against the common rule of respecting others' property rights and personal space. It also puts the safety of his neighbor and their family at risk, which is an unjust tradeoff for the life of Hank's son. This situation is a classic example of the moral dilemma of utilitarianism versus rights. On the one hand, the outcome of saving Hank's son's life may bring more overall happiness; on the other hand, the means by which this is achieved goes against basic principles of morality and justice. Therefore, it is not morally acceptable for Hank to break all the windows in his neighbor's house.
